posts.com:
Hey OP, I find breaking their necks to be much easier than coning them and cutting their throat. You can use something called a Hopper Popper that you just slide their heads into and then pull on their back legs to break their neck. You can also use a straight piece of wood or a metal bar (like a broom handle) to place behind their ears while they're laying on the ground, hold the handle down with your foot then pull straight up on their back legs to break the neck.

Don't feed the body pelt to your dogs there's too much fur and it can cause blockages. Dry the raw feet and ears for dog treats. You can also give your dogs the heart and liver (once you remove the gallbladder) if you don't want the livers for yourself. Rabbit livers are great fried.

>>18687768
There was never a time where supermarkets (starting with Piggly Wiggly) didn't converge with mass-produced, mass-processed industrial foodstuffs. It went hand in hand with the rise of convenience culture that was born out of two world wars. If anything things were way worse because of shittier standards and practices and lack of alternatives. You have way less cancerous niche food options in today's world compared to the last century.

You have to go back before WWI to get locally grown produce that came from specialty tradesmen. Basically your household would have seperate running tabs with your local butcher, baker, fishmonger, greengrocer ect, which would be delivered after placing an order and the quality of what you got really varied depending on how good he was at his job, if he was trying to diddle you, and how much business you gave him. If he was the only game in town you might be stuck with shitty low-grade products. You were also hamstringed by seasonal availability and prices could swing drastically based on shortages and surplus. You can forget about having pork in the summer or strawberries in winter. Most of you wouldn't be able to handle it.

>>18687715
Uhh no dude. You might want to do a little more research on what kind of food was in supermarkets back in the 50's and 60's.

Mass produced canned food was basically invented to feed soldiers during WWII, and after the war it took off in supermarkets and had a big influence on other food industries. Companies were racing to find the cheapest way to produce food at mass scales and they wanted it to be shelf stable to during this time period is when all kinds of whacky preservatives were being introduced. You also got shit like Wonderbread, which is basically chemically bleached flour that is "enriched" with the nutrients that were bleached out to begin with. So the food looks better and might taste better, but it's not really healthier for you than just a home-made loaf of bread made with flour, water, yeast, and salt.

There were also less food safety laws and little regulations regarding nutrition labeling. Plastic packaging would have been the least of your concerns lmao.

>>18693656
Tasting notes for anyone interested.

The beer is near syrupy, and pretty sweet. Being a barrel aged blend of barleywine and stout it tastes close to what you'd think.

Loads of chocolate from the stout, and dried fruits and caramel from the barleywine. The bourbon barrel adds some nice complexity and a hints of that good coconut barrel flavor.

Overall I would say that the beer pulls of the mix b/w stout and barleywine extremely well. A little sweet for my tastes, but it is perfectly smooth with big flavors and a long lasting finish.

Overall NOT WORTH IT. I would gladly pay 20 bucks for the bottle tho.

The easiest thing to do is just grab a stainless stell brew basket on amazon like pic related.
It doesn't really mater what brand they are all pretty similar.
Or the mesh ones made by finum
Then you can just brew in a mug.
If you want some cheap loose leaf try out vahdam, or ahmad.
If you want to try some nicer stuff order a couple teas from yunnansourcing.us the teas are sorted by popularity so look ate the top listings for different loose leaf categories and pick out a few teas that sound good based on the descriptions.
If you have any questions or need tips just ask in the thread.
Godspeed, you can make it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18677254
>nice cups
You don't need anything fancy. If you want Western style, get literally any mug from the dollar store or whatever and you should be good. You're looking for maybe 300-400ml volume for "teabag" style steeps which is a standard cup/mug. If you want a really quick and easy way to test volume pour a can of coke into it and if it fills close to the rim you're good.
If you want to do gong fu cha which is a lot more involved you can get a Gaiwan which is a lidded cup and should cost you about $10 off Amazon or aliexpress or wherever, will "replace" your brew basket (although you can pour your gaiwan into the brew basket to strain out leaves if you want super clean tea)
In terms of "nice" gongfu cups I actually use these cheap porcelain "appetizer" bowls from Walmart. They're just big enough for my 120ml Gaiwan and they were pretty cheap, although you should be able to find reasonably priced tea cups/yunomi on Amazon/Aliexpress too.
Tea can cost as much or as little as you want it to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Today's sip:
"Red Red Robe" from W2T
https://white2tea.com/products/red-red-robe
It is a black tea Yancha hybrid.

Parameters:
12.5g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with flash steeps

Notes:
Sweet and tart fruit, ripe plums, apples, raspberries, rhubarb.
Strong lasting sweetness.
Spicy, cinnamon and complimentary spices, lightly tingly.
Some toasty roasted savory notes.
Some floral aromatics.
Mild bitterness, low astringency, moderately drying
It reminds me a bit of a fruit crisp with a cinnamon oatmeal topping.

Conclusion:
I highly recommend it for the price especially if you like Yancha and mild sweet black teas. No real complaints. It is only 13.2¢/g if you buy a 250g bag. Seems like a great daily drinker. I will probably grab a big bag myself next time I order fromW2T.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18686543
Its basically bulletproof coffee but with brick tea.
Simmer 5-6 grams of some hei cha brick tea in .75 litres of water for 20 minutes, cut the heat. Strain out the tea leaves and return the liquid to the pot, add .25 litres of whole milk. Turn heat on just to get it up to temp, dont cook the milk. Then place in blender with a pat of butter and a small pinch of salt. Blend untill frothy pour in cups and serve.

Yeah, that's a loose leaf Chinese black tea. Some Chinese teas are very distinct and I could tell you exactly what it is (something like spring snail, for example) but that could be anything. I would expect it to be a relatively common and pedestrian Chinese red tea; I don't see a lot of gold tips but I'm not sure how well those hold up to 30 years of age. It's likely a Keemun since that's the most popular and Western-friendly option or maybe a Lapsang Souchong (does it have any sort of smokey flavor to it?)

Mud and leaves seems to be a very safe bet for teapots. Ive read that they have some of the nicer examples of nixing pieces.
That guy looks like it will have a really fast pour and i like the large knob on the lid, makes it much easier to grip securely and to hold it with your thumb well pouring. That said don't be afraid to hold the lid in place with your other hand while pouring. I had to do that with one of my pots for a while before i got the hand of holding the lid with my thumb.
Only other tip is while looking at, examining the pot etc or showing it to somone else remove the lid and place it on the table, and only pick up one part at a time. Its much safer that way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18689653
Yeah teapots are fun, very satisfying.
Its interesting how different they pour with plain water vs when you are brewing tea. The construction on that looks really nice, i like how clean the holes for the spout are.
They are always going to pour a little bit slower than a gaiwan but that's just part of the fun.
Its fun to experiment with brewing different teas and see how they clay affects the body and flavor vs brewing in porcelain.
In my limited experience the first few brews in a new pot can have a pronounced muting effect but they usually level out as they get used and settle into the effect they will normally have on your teas after 5 or so sessions.
Make sure to leave it to dry with the lid off after use you can put it back on after a day or two if the post is resting.

Ive been eyeing that fried tea for a while but havent bit. I haven't really seen if for sale elsewhere.
I can only go by the description on their website
>Introduction:
>Jieyang fried tea is a famous traditional tea. After the green tea leaves are evaporated at high temperature to soften the water, and then repeatedly fried, the leaves change from turquoise green to reddish brown. The green tea made with heavy fire is the characteristic of fried tea, and the soup is yellow and red. Jieyang Stir-Fried Tea is famous for its strong taste and a little sweetness, and it does not hurt the stomach after long-term drinking.
From another listing
>Traditional tea from Guangdong province. It has a strong characteristic aroma of green roasted tea and a bright complex taste.
>It is produced in the same places as the more famous Guandunskie oolongs, such as Feng Juan tribute Cong or Chaozhou cha. This tea is not known outside China. It can be said that this is a tea place in Guangdong province. Made from the same raw materials as most oolongs in this province. In the final stage of cooking tea is roasted by hand, in special boilers. Hence its strong and characteristic aroma and original taste, with a taste of fried chestnuts. Perfect for every day.
It seems like it repeatedly wok fried or otherwise roasted instead of the charcoal roast you usually see on oolongs. Im guessing the roast on the darker ones will be fairly intense which as the description says makes it easy on the stomach but the flavor isn't for everyone. Its one of those tea i imagine old Chinese guys sitting around drinking all day.
https://www.fullchea-tea.com/c/fried-tea-0386

I'm in the US visiting relatives and I finally understand why Americans are so fat.

It's the amount of choice and variety. If you go to the frozen foods section of a supermarket in Europe for example the selection is pretty humble. If you go to the US it's just freezer and freezer of a million different no-effort meals that are actually pretty good. I bought frozen gyoza, empenadas and a bunch of other shit and it's all at least decent.

There's a million different types of ice creams and flavors. There's a seemingly infinite number of cereals, chips, snacks, spreads, cheeses, deli meats, steak cuts. I walked in the other day and I was genuinely overwhelmed by the sheer amount of choice.

If I lived in the US there is a high chance I'd be buying easy-to-prepare half ready meals and not put much effort into vegetables or eating normally.

>>18688808
If you make a $100/hour and a chef costs $30/hour, instead of cooking for yourself it's more cost effective to work for an extra hour and pay the chef to do it. If you earn $8/hour you'd be losing money paying the chef so it's better forgo the extra work and cook for yourself.

It's the same principle here. The savings you get from cooking yourself are more valuable the poorer you are, as you have lower opportunity cost incurred by cooking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18693511
It's been packed in a meatpacking facility where random cuts which don't make the cut, or whatever leftover trimmings get mushed up in a tube.
The regular packages in styrofoam with foil on top are what your local butcher, or store produces. It's not as easy to transport. Here in Canuckistan, one can be cheaper than the other, or one can be of better quality than the other, there are no rules.

One thing is certain, the chubs last WAY longer because there's no air inside to oxidize them, unlike the classic styrofoam packaging. They're also less likely to ooze juices out, get pierced or fall out... and people aren't able to pick and throw them around, due to the opaque packaging material, which is why they're usually cheaper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Polymer chemist here. Water is a non-solvent for pretty much all common household plastics except of course poly(vinyl alcohol), some acetates, and poly(ethylene) glycol. That being said, the cheap plastic used for those kettles is probably some type of polyester, polycarbonate or polystyrene copolymer, which are not water soluble and would not swell appreciably in boiling water. The only way you would get microplastics in you then is if you repeatedly damaged the inside of the kettle with some object like a fork or something for some reason. There is, however, a high likelihood that plasticizers in the plastic might leach into your water after prolonged use. Plasticizers are small molecules added during manufacturing to help plastics become workable/moldable (i.e., plastic) at high temperatures. Hot water might assist in the permeation of plasticizers through the plastic (see: the whole BPA scare).

Interesting. Poschl is a brand I've somehow neglected to try over the years. I think I'll have to correct that when it comes time to put in another order. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18680718
They produce a lot of snuffs under various sub-brands. I remember getting some "Jump" branded snuff in Austria several years ago, that was made by Poschl (I think it was an Austrian-market specific product). If you go to MrSnuff, you'll find they have a pretty wide variety of tinned snuffs. Unfortunately, I cannot order from them anymore (customs issues), and getting tobacco shipped from a continental online shop is an exercise in frustration and/or extreme patience.

I haven't tried many of their tinned snuffs, but I really liked Ozona President (which they apparently do not produce anymore, for some reason). Lowenprise is too cloying for my taste (too much anise). Gletscher Prise used to be good, but I think they changed the recipe, for the worse, a few years ago. Andechs Kloster is good, though some people might find it a bit too sweet. Gawith Apricot (yes, it's made by Poschl, despite carrying the name of a different snuff maker) is acceptable for a fruit-flavored snuff, the menthol helps rein in the apricot flavor's 'perfumy' tendencies.
Of the schmalzlers, I'd go for Sudfrucht (SF) and/or Doppelaroma (D), for that classic jamminess. However, Poschl schmalzlers are packed in sachets, and they tend to lose aroma if stored too long before use. You might occasionally get a dud. This is different from something like Bernard's Gekachelter Virginie, which is super harsh, very strong manure smell right out of the box, and actually benefits from air exposure to mellow out.

Yeah drying out can be a problem especially if you use snuff rather frequently ie. topping up multiple uses per session etc. and not cleaning properly which I would imagine is common among snuff users. I typically am a very moderate user however, keeping it mostly to 2-4 sniffs per day and don't have much of a problem with it. Also just to put it out there I blow and clean my nose grug style. Its a pretty private habit anyway since there aren't many users out there and I don't worry about it what people might think of it. Fact is its one of the healthiest and enjoyable ways to use tobacco, and last I checked the majority of our taste receptors are in the nasal cavity.

As one can imagine this is a dirt cheap habit. Not only is the price of snuff relatively way cheaper compared with every other tobacco product I know of but also aside from the schmalzlers everything can easily be rehydrated if a batch goes dry so you can be frugal about it that way as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18689488
Yes. Mid tier or better pizza delivery is ~$30 where I live when you factor in all the delivery fees. The dough recipe I follow takes 5 minutes to make, plus four folds over an hour which equates to about 10 minutes of active time. It sits in the fridge overnight and then comes out to the counter the next day. My sauce recipe takes a half hour, but almost all of that is just simmering time. It takes another 5 minutes to prepare the pan and stretch the dough. 5 more for cutting toppings and assembling the pizza. Total active time is 20-30 minutes split over two days, and this scales nicely to two or three pies. I use pizza as a sink for my leftover meats and veggies from the previous few days which makes it even more convenient. My wife works in a hydroponic herb farm so many of the seasonings are free.

It's genuinely one of the least involved and most economical meals I regularly make.

>>18690404
2001 I converted my motorcycle to run on alcohol. Set up a still in my shed to produce fuel.
Did it for 6 years.
Made a mistake and ran empty one day. Took lunch break to buy 99% rubbing alcohol, boss caught me pouring it into my tank. Company did electronic component work for printers, wireless, motion control systems, some on DOJ contracts...
about 2 weeks later the FBI seized my wheels and still, got a $1200 fine and threatened with jail time. Banned from buying alcohol for 3 years, and prohibited to modify vehicles or own a motorcycle for 5 years.
Gag order about the case ended in 2016. Tried to get copies of the records of it in 2017... FBI claimed that the whole event never happened so there were no records.
Protip, be extremely secret about running a still.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18680411
Gravy can mean any savory thick sauce. Chicken Tikka Masala? That sauce is a gravy. Traditional brown gravy is just thickened drippings from a roast, perhaps with some broth. But then there's country style gravy, which is more like a bechamel. And some Italians will refer to their tomato sauce as gravy, especially when its simmered all day with some sausages and meatballs. There's also mushroom or onion gravy. Another weird one is red-eye gravy which is made with coffee and served with a thick slice of fried cured ham.
I would imagine its a similar confusion when Americans hear how many things you would call a pudding, when we use a much narrower meaning over here.

>>18690765
Scotch is from Scotland. Whisky usually denotes scotch styles but you also have Maker's Mark bourbon and the entire US legal code on alcohol which spells it whisky. Whiskey is an Irish spelling that became more common in the US with the migration, but if you read old letters, people use both interchangeably because spelling wasn't formalized until well after Webster's dictionary came out.

>>18690891
It started using unmalted barley because fuck English taxes and US Prohibition nearly killed the industry of over a thousand distilleries which ushered in the use of column stills. Pot stilled Irish is really good, though not usually as complex or funky as scotch, and shares a lot with American styles that aren't bourbon.

KC guy here. Want to send a care package to yourself or passing through town and want to hit up the best bbq check out

Jack's Stack BBQ (the upscale place)
Joe's Kansas City (the crowded lunch place)
Danny Edward's BBQ (the almost always closed place)
Bryant's BBQ (the best black bbq place)
Char Bar (the best bar)
Q39 (the best hipster bbq)
BB's Lawnside BBQ (The best bbq and blues, cajun style food)
Zarda BBQ (white bbq in the suburbs and they also smoke ribs and sell them in upscale supermarkets, and they have a Sneed Sandwich)

Bourdain liked BB's best. Bryant's is "the president's choice". Q39 is the hangout of the KC Chiefs.

>>18693241
The amount of citrus I'm likely to consume tends to greatly exceed the amount of zest and/or peel I'm likely to use, and the consumption periods are generally very unequal from week to week. I don't know if the oils on peel keep particularly well in the fridge. I wouldn't try refrigerating grated zest for more than a day.

You can dry peeled zest (using a vegetable peeler -- I find this gets better results than eyeballing with a chef's knife btw) in the oven which should keep significantly longer and be much more potent than fresh orange peel. (Kenji uses dry peel, fresh zest, and juice in his orange chicken recipe, which I made earlier this week and was super good (3/4 sugar quantity is workable if you think typical Chink-Amer food is too sweet, but lower than that and you'll regret it): https://www.seriouseats.com/the-best-chinese-orange-chicken-recipe

Personally I find the challenge more that good oranges for juice (for cooking/baking/drinks) are not usually good oranges for snacking, and I don't like stocking an excess of fruit.

>>18692120
How did you get the pierogis to stay closed? A lot of mine burst

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18692126
I think an easy issue to happen is for the filling to get on the edge of your seam and to stop the dough from binding properly. Try to make sure non of the filling touches the edge, the potato acts as a barrier.
Additionally, a tiny bit water, but if you are using too much water on the edge they wont bind either. You want it to just barely be moist.
If you are having issues with the body of the dumpling bursting or tearing, then your dough just needs to be more stretchy. I'm not the best at making good doughs yet, so i just make it a little thicker to avoid tearing.

The photo looks really nice for a cheap dish like that

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18692904
I think you can use the salty water for canned beans, so I did for the salt, but be careful about using any beans water if it’s dried and you soaked/cooked in it, as that shit will make you sick. I also threw in some more water from the tap because shell pasta soaks it up a lot to expand.
I cooked the sauce for probably 5-10 minutes before putting in the pasta to get it hot. I cooked at a medium to high heat until it was bubbling.
Be sure to use spices lying around or just cough up enough for it, as they go really well with tomatoes. My favourite to use is paprika, chilli, pepper, and turmeric, but you can try whatever. Spice and herbs and shit remain cheap and last ages. I even put a sprinkle of peppermint in mine to try it and it was surprisingly good to have a tinge of something contrasting.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18682820
>what makes a Banh Mi a Banh Mi?
The bread. The Bread makes the Banh Mi.
Super crispy and super thin crust, extremely fluffy inside (no big gaps like western's breads) that perfectly soaks up whatever sauce you pour on it. No, it's not baguette. Most translation call it Vietnamese Baguette to make it easier for the reader to visualize what it is.
That's it. The Bread. The Banh Mi. Two but One..
No, the fillings have nothing to do with it. There are multiple styles of fillings for Banh Mi so you can't generalize it into pork and veggies.
There's also Banh Mi Cha Ca (Bread with Fish Paste Sticks (sticks are pounded fish with seasoning and dill, deep fried)), Banh Mi Op La (sunny side up Bread), etc.

>otherwise completely unspecified fillings
No. It's a Vietnamese baguette (this can't be substituted), some kind of protein, pickled carrot and daikon, fresh cilantro jalapeno, and often cucumber. Sometimes it has liver pate and sometimes it has butter or mayo. The protein can be any number of things, but they're typically like, you know, Vietnamese preparations and flavors. If you stick salami and mayo in a baguette and call it a banh mi everyone would call you an idiot.

posts.com: The East Side German Restaurant in New Britain, Connecticut, is a famous local German beer hall themed eatery. The restaurant is owned by Jorge Löderschnicht and his wife, Eva Löderschnicht. Jorge, pictured here, inherited the building from his mother 6 years ago and has adapted the restaurant to serve the needs of the burgeoning German/Puerto Rican fusion culture that has developed in the “Germantown” neighborhood. Once a bustling center of German immigrants, as immigration patterns changed the areas population became majority Hispanic, but the Germans of old did not neglect to pass down their cultural traditions to the newcomers. The menu at East Side reflects this blending of cultures with options such as “Chorizo Bratwurst”, Saurkraut Empanadas, and their biggest seller, the Schnitzel with Rice and Beans Combo Meal. The restaurant frequently hosts local dance and music competitions featuring everything from Tango to Polka. The menu is listed in German, Spanish, and English, and it is customary for New Britain locals to order one item in each language. Adobo Kartoffelknödel is the most commonly ordered in English due to out of towners having difficulty with its pronunciation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Waiters at East Side were mandated to address all guests with the title of “Herr” or “Frau”, but that has slacked in the years following the COVID 19 pandemic. Most of the staff quit during the pandemic, choosing safety, social distancing, and unemployment checks over risking their lives in the deadliest pandemic in history. For now, you’re much more likely to hear a “Señor”, as most of the staff has been replaced by illegal Mexican immigrants. Instead of hearing the chefs of the roaring beer hall kitchen scream “FUEUR SHPATZEL” you’re much more likely to hear a “ I needa speetz señor”.

>>18685726
You can use truncated cone filters in a conical pour over cone.
1. open up filter
2. place filter in one cupped hand (the anvil)
3. make a fist with your other hand (the hammer)
4. insert hammer fist into filter and rotate fist to round out the bottom
5. place paper into cone and sooth out paper seam
The scrunched, rounded bottom of the paper has no effect on the cup of coffee other than making the paper sit correctly in the funnel.

posts.name: swaglord
posts.com:
>>18688287
shot progresses from acid > sweet > bitter. you'll get a whole lot of value out of getting a scale and using it to stop your shot by weight instead of just timing it - and also weighing your dose each time. doesnt even need to be an expensive scale. can't really help much with diagnosing shots if you arent keeping variables as constant as possible.

typical dialing in would be get your 1:2 (ex. 18 in 36 out) shot in the 25-30 second range via adjusting grind size and then taste. if it's too sour, decrease yield. too bitter increase yield. if its both too sour and too bitter youve either ground too fine and are channeling or your puck prep sucks and you're channeling so you have an uneven extraction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18692740
Expect that your results will be better than expected, pretty much right away. Most of a roast's quality is just end color. Loads of roasters (home and pro) stop here, because it tastes good, and they did it, so it must be better or optimal or whatever. But this is not the case. There are large gains to be had by understanding roasting, using good roast logging equipment and software, and being very critical of what you produce.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18692740
Trial and error. It takes a while to get roasting figured out. It takes a while to figure out how roast affects every coffee. It takes a while to figure out what types of coffee you like. I approach every first batch of a new coffee at a city roast, which will be somewhere in the middle of first crack. A good, balanced medium. Adjust lighter or darker according to taste on successive roasts. You'll be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18692794
Yep. It's not difficult. It just takes patience and persistence to get good at it. You can't miss first crack. It sounds like popcorn. Starts as a few random pops, then crescendos into a rolling pop, then slowly fades. Second crack is the threshold of dark roast. The beans go quiet for a little bit, then they crack again, but more softly like rice crispies.

My intuition tells me the Yirgacheffe will taste the best between a light roast (10-20 seconds from the first pops) to a medium (right in the middle of the rolling pops), and the Sumatra will taste best at a full city (darker side of medium, just as the middle of the your rolling first crack begins winding down) and a vienna (lighter dark roast, as soon as you hear the beginning of second crack).
